sn7.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn7.8:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn7.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aggikabhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa sappinā pāyaso sannihito hoti:
sn7.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time ghee and milk-rice had been set out for the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper, who thought,

sn7.8:1.3.eng: “I will serve the sacred flame! I will perform the fire sacrifice!”

sn7.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn7.8:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.

sn7.8:2.2.pli: Rājagahe sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caramāno yena aggikabhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.8:2.2.eng: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood in Rājagaha, he approached Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper’s home and stood to one side.

sn7.8:2.3.pli: Addasā kho aggikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ piṇḍāya ṭhitaṃ.
sn7.8:2.3.eng: Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper saw him standing for alms

sn7.8:3.1.eng: “One who’s accomplished in the three knowledges,
sn7.8:3.1.comm: For him, the “three knowledges” would have been the Vedas.

sn7.8:3.2.eng: of good birth and ample learning,

sn7.8:3.4.comm: An oblation of milk-rice may be offered to various deities, and is commonly associated with fertility rites. It should be offered to brahmins (eg. Khādira Gṛhyasūtra 4.3; Pāraskara Gṛhyasūtra 3.9.8; Gobhila Gṛhyasūtra 3.8, 4.6.13; Śāṅkhāyana Gṛhyasūtra 3.11.16, 4.16.5), but only those who study the Vedas (Gautama Dharmasūtra 1.5.30). It should not be cooked for one’s own consumption (Manu 5.7). It counteracts inauspicious dreams (Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 11.4). Manu 3.271 says such an offering is efficacious for a year. Compare Snp 3.4, where rice cake is offered instead. | Somaṁ is so imaṁ, not a reference to soma.

sn7.8:4.3.eng: if they’re filthy and corrupt within,

sn7.8:4.4.eng: with a following gained by fawning.

sn7.8:5.1.eng: One who knows their past lives,
sn7.8:5.1.comm: This verse sets out the Buddha”s “three knowledges”: recollection of past lives, clairvoyance of rebirth, and ending of rebirth.

sn7.8:5.2.eng: sees heaven and places of loss,

sn7.8:5.3.eng: and has attained the ending of rebirth,

sn7.8:5.4.eng: is a sage of perfect insight.

sn7.8:6.2.eng: a brahmin is a master of the three knowledges.

sn7.8:7.2.eng: The worthy one is a brahmin.”

sn7.8:8.1.eng: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.
sn7.8:8.1.comm: See SN 2.9:7.3 and note. Also note that, while gāthā is sometimes said to exclude Vedic verse, this is not the case (see eg. Rig Veda 1.190.01, 8.71.14, 8.92.02; Atharva Veda 10.10.20, 15.6.4, 20.103.1; 3.2.4.16; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.5.3.11, 13.1.5.6; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.17.9). It was, however, said to be a distinct form of verse within the broader Vedic corpus (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.6.8,  11.5.7.10).

sn7.8:8.2.eng: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.

sn7.8:8.3.eng: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.

sn7.8:8.4.eng: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.
sn7.8:8.4.comm: “Since there is such a principle” is dhamme sati, “there being the law of nature”.

sn7.8:9.1.eng: Serve with other food and drink

sn7.8:9.2.eng: the consummate one, the great seer,

sn7.8:9.3.eng: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.

sn7.8:9.4.eng: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

sn7.8:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aggikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.8:10.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper said to the Buddha,

sn7.8:10.3.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā aggikabhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.8:10.3.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper became one of the perfected.

sn7.9:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati sundarikāya nadiyā tīre.
sn7.9:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Kosalan lands on the bank of the Sundarikā river.
sn7.9:1.1.comm: This Sutta, and its expanded parallel at Snp 3.4, contains a dense array of allusions and plays on Vedic concepts.

sn7.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo sundarikāya nadiyā tīre aggiṃ juhati, aggihuttaṃ paricarati.
sn7.9:1.2.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā was serving the sacred flame and performing the fire sacrifice on the bank of the Sundarikā.
sn7.9:1.2.comm: This is evidently the midday fire oblation described at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.2.3. A brahmin householder, worshiping when the sun is at its most powerful and the forces of darkness weakest, renders offerings to Agni so that he will drive away evils. | The Sundarikā was a sacred river (MN 7:20.3). Bathing in the ford there was said to bring beauty (Mahābhārata 3.82.51).

sn7.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo aggiṃ juhitvā aggihuttaṃ paricaritvā uṭṭhāyāsanā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi:
sn7.9:1.3.eng: Then he surveyed the four quarters, wondering,

sn7.9:1.4.eng: “Now who might eat the leftovers of this oblation?”
sn7.9:1.4.comm: The concept of “leftovers” (sesa) is supremely important in the ritual, for what is burned away is for the gods and humans live on what is left. Normally leavings would have been given to a brahmin and not lower castes (Manu 4.80, 3.249; Khādira Gṛhyasūtra 2.1.29). | At Snp 3.4:10.5 the offering is specified as a sacrificial cake (pūraḷāsa, Sanskrit puroḍāśa).

sn7.9:1.5.pli: Addasā kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle sasīsaṃ pārutaṃ nisinnaṃ.
sn7.9:1.5.eng: He saw the Buddha meditating at the root of a certain tree with his robe pulled over his head.

sn7.9:1.6.pli: Disvāna vāmena hatthena habyasesaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena kamaṇḍaluṃ gahetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.9:1.6.eng: Taking the leftovers of the oblation in his left hand and a pitcher in the right he approached the Buddha.

sn7.9:1.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sundarikabhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa padasaddena sīsaṃ vivari.
sn7.9:1.7.eng: When he heard Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā’s footsteps the Buddha uncovered his head.

sn7.9:1.8.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo “muṇḍo ayaṃ bhavaṃ, muṇḍako ayaṃ bhavan”ti tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
sn7.9:1.8.eng: Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā thought, “This man is shaven, he is shaven!” And he wanted to turn back.

sn7.9:1.11.eng: Why don’t I go to him and ask about his birth?”

sn7.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.9:2.1.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā went up to the Buddha, and said to him,

sn7.9:2.2.comm: From here the Sutta omits a passage from Snp 3.4:3.1–14.1.

sn7.9:3.1.eng: “Don’t ask about birth, ask about conduct;
sn7.9:3.1.comm: Here we rejoin Snp 3.4:14.1 for a time.

sn7.9:3.2.eng: for the fire of Jātaveda is born from sticks.
sn7.9:3.2.comm: The line plays with jāti (“birth”), jāyati (“give birth”), and jātaveda. The latter is a Vedic word for fire. Its meaning is obscure, but I think the sense is jāta (“those who have been born”, i.e. “mortals”) plus vedas (“knowledge”), i.e. “one who brings knowledge to mortals”. This is the fire-god Agni, who comes down from the sun to the sacrificial fire, bringing light and awareness and Vedic knowledge to those who have been born, namely mortal humans. In this passage, it implies that anyone who “has been born” can “give birth” to “knowledge” regardless of their “birth”.

sn7.9:3.3.eng: A steadfast sage, even though from a low class family,

sn7.9:3.4.eng: is a thoroughbred checked by conscience.

sn7.9:4.1.eng: Tamed by truth, fulfilled by taming,

sn7.9:4.2.eng: a complete knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey—
sn7.9:4.2.comm: “Complete knowledge master” is vedantagū, which in the Vedic system would mean, “one who has completely mastered the Vedas”.

sn7.9:4.3.eng: that’s who a sacrificer should invite,
sn7.9:4.3.comm: Upavhayati occurs only here and DN 20:11.15 in Pali. It is  Vedic term for invoking or calling up blessings in a whisper. | From here the text diverges again from Snp 3.4:15.3, which inserts a long series of verses.

sn7.9:4.4.eng: and offer a timely oblation <j>to one worthy of a religious donation.”

sn7.9:5.1.eng: “My sacrificial offering <j>must have been well performed,

sn7.9:5.2.eng: since I have met such a knowledge master!

sn7.9:5.3.eng: It’s because I’d never met anyone like you

sn7.9:5.4.eng: that others ate the leftover oblation.

sn7.9:6.2.eng: The worthy one is a brahmin.”
sn7.9:6.2.comm: Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.24.4 says that one performing the fire ritual with true wisdom may even offer to an outcaste.

sn7.9:7.1.eng: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.

sn7.9:7.2.eng: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.

sn7.9:7.3.eng: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.

sn7.9:7.4.eng: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.

sn7.9:8.1.eng: Serve with other food and drink

sn7.9:8.2.eng: the consummate one, the great seer,

sn7.9:8.3.eng: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.

sn7.9:8.4.eng: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

sn7.9:9.1.pli: “Atha kassa cāhaṃ, bho gotama, imaṃ habyasesaṃ dammī”ti?
sn7.9:9.1.eng: “Then, Mister Gotama, to whom should I give the leftovers of this oblation?”

sn7.9:9.2.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yasseso habyaseso bhutto sammā pariṇāmaṃ gaccheyya aññatra, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatassa vā tathāgatasāvakassa vā.
sn7.9:9.2.eng: “Brahmin, I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who can properly digest these leftovers, except for the Realized One or one of his disciples.
sn7.9:9.2.comm: At Snp 3.4:34.4 the Buddha recommends giving instead to arahants.

sn7.9:9.3.pli: Tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, taṃ habyasesaṃ appaharite vā chaḍḍehi appāṇake vā udake opilāpehī”ti.
sn7.9:9.3.eng: Well then, brahmin, throw out those leftovers where there is little that grows, or drop them into water that has no living creatures.”
sn7.9:9.3.comm: In a text on the agnihotra, Prajāpatī is depicted as pouring the oblation on plants and water (Kāṭhaka Saṃhitā 6.2). The Āpastamba Dharmasūtra says that the student must “not leave any food uneaten. If he is unable to do so, he should bury the leftovers in the ground, (or) throw them in the water” (1.4.12). See too Śathapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.8.5.9, where the stake for the heart of the sacrificial beast is disposed on the muddy ground between water and dry land, so as to disturb neither.

sn7.9:10.1.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo taṃ habyasesaṃ appāṇake udake opilāpesi.
sn7.9:10.1.eng: So Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā dropped the leftover oblation in water that had no living creatures.

sn7.9:10.2.pli: Atha kho so habyaseso udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati.
sn7.9:10.2.eng: And when those leftovers were placed in the water, they sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.

sn7.9:10.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma phālo divasaṃsantatto udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati;
sn7.9:10.3.eng: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day. If you placed it in the water, it would sizzle and hiss, steaming and fuming.

sn7.9:10.4.pli: evameva so habyaseso udake pakkhitto cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati sandhūpāyati sampadhūpāyati.
sn7.9:10.4.eng: In the same way, when those leftovers were placed in the water, they sizzled and hissed, steaming and fuming.

sn7.9:11.1.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.9:11.1.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā, shocked and awestruck, went up to the Buddha, and stood to one side.

sn7.9:11.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho sundarikabhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ bhagavā gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.9:11.2.eng: The Buddha addressed him in verse:
sn7.9:11.2.comm: In these verses, the Buddha systematically critiques and realigns the fire sacrifice.

sn7.9:12.2.eng: don’t imagine this is purity, for it’s just external.

sn7.9:12.3.pli: Na hi tena suddhiṃ kusalā vadanti,
sn7.9:12.3.eng: For those who are skilled say this is no way to purity,

sn7.9:12.4.eng: when one seeks purity in externals.

sn7.9:13.1.eng: I’ve given up kindling firewood, brahmin,

sn7.9:13.2.eng: now I light only the inner flame.

sn7.9:13.3.comm: This passage plays on the homonyms samādahati (“kindle”, root meaning “to burn”) and samādahati (“serene”, “stilled”, “immersed”, root meaning “to place”). He no longer “burns” the sacred flame, but “is serene” with the inner light of samādhi.

sn7.9:13.4.eng: I am a perfected one leading the spiritual life.

sn7.9:14.1.eng: Conceit, brahmin, is the burden of your pack,
sn7.9:14.1.comm: Such passages of equivalences or connections are characteristic of post-Vedic literature. For example, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.6 says the juhū spoon is speech, the upabhṛt cup  the mind, the dhruvā vessel the eye, the sruvā ladle the mental power, the bath the truth, the conclusion heaven. | A “pack” (khāri_) was originally “donkey-load”, but here it must be a heavy weight for a single person. The Buddha is saying that carrying around the cenceit of “self” is a heavy burden.

sn7.9:14.2.eng: anger your smoke, and lies your ashes.
sn7.9:14.2.comm: Smoke conveys the sacrifice to heaven (eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.7.133, “May smoke rise to the sky, light to heaven, may ash fill the earth). For smoke in the sense of “fuming”, see AN 4.200:13.1, MN 23:2.1. | Sacred ash, the purifying divine residue from the fire, was smeared on the forehead or body as a sign of holiness. Here, however, the implication is that when the “fuming” anger is cold, all that is left are the lies spoken in the heat of rage. The line plays with the curse that those who hate us should be reduced to ashes (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 6.6.3.10, see MN 93:18.19).

sn7.9:14.3.eng: The tongue is the ladle, the heart the fireplace;
sn7.9:14.3.comm: The sujā (Sanskrit sruvā) is a small ladle of udumbara fig wood. It is dipped into the ghee or milk, lapping like a tongue, a metaphor often deployed in the Rig Veda (1.61.5, 3.31.3, 5.1.3, 10.109.5). The sacrifice of ghee, honey, and milk is driven by the craving to experience such delicious tastes. | The jotiṭhāna (“fireplace”) was a depression in the ground in which the fire was kindled. Here joti must be translated “fire”, but it is the same word as “light” in the next line. The Buddha is saying that the light/fire is kindled in the heart (hadayaṁ jotiṭhānaṁ). This draws on Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.7, where the Self is the “light within the heart” (hṛdyantarjyoti).

sn7.9:14.4.eng: a well-tamed self is a person’s light.
sn7.9:14.4.comm: Attā … purisassa joti is a direct reference to Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.2. Janaka asks Yājñavalkya, “What is this person’s light?” (kiṃjyotirayaṃ puruṣa). Yājñavalkya answers, “The self, indeed, is his light” (ātmaivāsya jyotirbhavati). The key difference is the term “well-tamed” (sudanto). For the Buddha, what is known as a “self” is conditioned and changing, so must be developed, and only then becomes a blessing. In such cases, “self” is practically equivalent to “mind”.

sn7.9:15.1.eng: The teaching is a lake, brahmin, <j>into which ethics are the stairs,
sn7.9:15.1.comm: The lake (rahada) was a pool of water into which the sacrificer descends seeking renewal or protection (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.1.5.12, 4.4.5.10). | The tittha was the sacred bathing place, originally the stairs or descent that provided passage to the waters. | This verse occurs independently at SN 7.21:3.1.

sn7.9:15.2.eng: unclouded, praised by the fine to the good.

sn7.9:15.3.eng: There the knowledge masters go to bathe,

sn7.9:15.4.eng: and cross to the far shore with dry limbs.
sn7.9:15.4.comm: The use of deliberate paradox—bathe without getting wet—is characteristic of Vedic verse. The water rolls off them as it does a lotus.

sn7.9:16.1.eng: Truth, principle, restraint, the spiritual life,
sn7.9:16.1.comm: See similar sets of virtues at DN 30:1.6.2 and SN 24.6:1.7. | This verse seems clumsy to me, and I retain that in the translation.

sn7.9:16.2.eng: attaining divinity based on the middle, brahmin—
sn7.9:16.2.comm: “Attainment of divinity” (brahmapatti) is found in Brahmanical sense at Katha Upaniṣad 6.18.

sn7.9:16.3.eng: pay homage to the upright ones.
sn7.9:16.3.comm: The commentary says the t in sat is a mere particle, and the pronoun should be read as second person. | The “upright ones” are the arahants.

sn7.9:16.4.eng: I declare that man one who follows the teaching.”
sn7.9:16.4.comm: Dhammasārī is a unique phrase. Normally, sārī means “one who follows”, making this an abbreviation of dhammānusārī, a “follower of teachings”. Elsewhere, however, this refers only to a specific stage prior to stream-entry (SN 25.1:2.1). We do find dhammasāra elsewhere in the sense “heartwood of the teaching” (SN 55.43:5.3, Thag 16.3:18.2), and perhaps sārī here means “having the essence of”. This form is not attested in Pali, but it is found in Sanskrit. Such an option is not endorsed by the commentary, which supplies two possibilities. One relies on the causative form sāretvā, “one who makes unskilful qualities leave”. The second is curious: one is “covered by the sārī of Dhamma”. That this means the saree dress is confirmed by the subcommentary’s “dressed and decorated”. If correct, this may be the earliest occurrence of sārī in this sense; the standard Pali spelling is sāṭī. By this reading we might translate, “draped in the teaching”. | “That man” according to the commentary refers to one who practices in such a way.

sn7.9:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.9:17.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā said to the Buddha,

sn7.9:17.3.pli: aññataro ca panāyasmā bhāradvājo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn7.9:17.3.eng: And Venerable Bhāradvāja became one of the perfected.

sn8.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā vaṅgīso āḷaviyaṃ viharati aggāḷave cetiye āyasmatā nigrodhakappena upajjhāyena saddhiṃ.
sn8.1:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at Āḷavī’s premier shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
sn8.1:1.2.comm: This chapter features the poetry of Vaṅgīsa, the finest poet of the Sangha, providing a prose setting for his Theragāthā verses at Thag 21.1. There are notable differences between the two versions. In several passages, including this one, he reflects on the struggles he faced in his path, showing a high degree of self-awareness and persistence.

sn8.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā vaṅgīso navako hoti acirapabbajito ohiyyako vihārapālo.
sn8.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa was junior, recently gone forth. He had been left behind to look after the dwelling.

sn8.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho sambahulā itthiyo samalaṅkaritvā yena aggāḷavako ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu vihārapekkhikāyo.
sn8.1:1.4.eng: Then several women dressed in all their finery went to the monastery at Āḷavī’s premier shrine in order to inspect the dwelling.
sn8.1:1.4.comm: Period art depicts women as bare-breasted and draped in elaborate jewellery.

sn8.1:1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmato vaṅgīsassa tā itthiyo disvā anabhirati uppajjati, rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.
sn8.1:1.5.eng: When Vaṅgīsa saw them he became dissatisfied, with lust infecting his mind.
sn8.1:1.5.comm: “Dissatisfaction” (anabhirati) with his life of seclusion and celibacy.

sn8.1:1.7.pli: “alābhā vata me, na vata me lābhā; dulladdhaṃ vata me, na vata me suladdhaṃ;

sn8.1:1.8.pli: yassa me anabhirati uppannā, rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti, taṃ kutettha labbhā, yaṃ me paro anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādeyya.
sn8.1:1.8.eng: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?

sn8.1:1.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ attanāva attano anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādeyyan”ti.
sn8.1:1.9.eng: Why don’t I do it myself?”

sn8.1:1.10.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso attanāva attano anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādetvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.1:1.10.eng: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:

sn8.1:2.4.eng: by the rude thoughts of the Dark One.

sn8.1:3.1.eng: Even if a thousand warrior chiefs and great archers,
sn8.1:3.1.comm: There is some confusion regarding the Pali ugga (“warrior chief”). Pali commentaries and Sanskrit sources (Manu 10.9) speak of a caste called ugga (Sanskrit ugra), born of a khattiya father and a sudda mother. They were reviled as cruel, and their duty was to catch snakes and other underground vermin (Manu 10.49). This is not the aristocratic warriors referred to here. The distinction is noted in Medhātithi’s commentary to Manu 4.212, who says the Vedic ugra was a key figure in the king’s alliance, which is supported by the use at DN 3:2.7.2.

sn8.1:4.4.eng: for I stand firm in the teaching.

sn8.1:5.1.eng: I heard with my own ears

sn8.1:5.2.eng: from the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,

sn8.1:5.3.eng: about the path going to extinguishment;

sn8.1:6.1.eng: Wicked One, if you come near me

sn8.1:6.3.eng: I’ll make sure that you, Death,

sn8.1:6.4.eng: won’t even see the path I take.”

sn8.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati isigilipasse kāḷasilāyaṃ mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi.
sn8.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.

sn8.10:1.2.pli: Tesaṃ sudaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno cetasā cittaṃ samannesati vippamuttaṃ nirupadhiṃ.
sn8.10:1.2.eng: Thereupon, with his mind, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna checked to see whose mind was liberated and free of attachments.

sn8.10:1.4.pli: “ayaṃ kho bhagavā rājagahe viharati isigilipasse kāḷasilāyaṃ mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi.
sn8.10:1.4.eng: “The Buddha is staying on the slopes of Isigili … with five hundred perfected ones.

sn8.10:1.5.pli: Tesaṃ sudaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno cetasā cittaṃ samannesati vippamuttaṃ nirupadhiṃ.
sn8.10:1.5.eng: Mahāmoggallāna is checking to see whose mind is liberated and free of attachments.

sn8.10:1.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ bhagavato sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
sn8.10:1.6.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in the Buddha’s presence with fitting verses?”

sn8.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.10:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.10:2.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.10:2.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.10:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ bhagavato sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.10:2.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Mahāmoggallāna in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.10:3.1.eng: “As the sage, who has gone beyond suffering,

sn8.10:3.3.eng: he is revered by disciples with the three knowledges,

sn8.10:5.1.eng: That is how those endowed <j>with many fine qualities
sn8.10:5.1.comm: Emend anekākārasampannaṁ to anekākārasampannā per Bodhi’s Connected Discourses, note 527.

sn8.10:5.4.comm: I take aṅga (“factor”) as implying “path factor”, and ākāra (“attribute”) as indicating the Buddha’s qualities.

sn8.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sattahi ca upāsakasatehi sattahi ca upāsikāsatehi anekehi ca devatāsahassehi.
sn8.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants, seven hundred male and seven hundred female lay followers, and many thousands of deities.
sn8.11:1.1.comm: Campā is modern Champapur near Bhagalpur in Bihar state, not far from West Bengal. It is near the eastern-most reach of the Buddha’s journeys. Campā was the capital of Aṅga, one of the sixteen “great nations” (mahājanapadā). It was a flourishing trade center, and became a sacred city for the Jains. | Gaggarā, an onomatopoeic reduplication (“gargle”), is the name of a number of rivers and whirlpools in Sanskrit (cp. the modern Ghaggar River in north-west India). | This is the only time an assembly of this size is reported.

sn8.11:1.2.pli: Tyāssudaṃ bhagavā atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
sn8.11:1.2.eng: But the Buddha outshone them all in beauty and glory.

sn8.11:1.4.pli: “ayaṃ kho bhagavā campāyaṃ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sattahi ca upāsakasatehi sattahi ca upāsikāsatehi anekehi ca devatāsahassehi.
sn8.11:1.4.eng: “The Buddha is staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants, seven hundred male and seven hundred female lay followers, and many thousands of deities.

sn8.11:1.5.pli: Tyāssudaṃ bhagavā atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
sn8.11:1.5.eng: And he outshines them all in beauty and glory.

sn8.11:1.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāya gāthāya abhitthaveyyan”ti.
sn8.11:1.6.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”

sn8.11:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.11:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.11:2.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.11:2.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.11:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāya gāthāya abhitthavi:
sn8.11:2.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.11:3.1.eng: “Like the moon on a cloudless night,

sn8.11:3.3.eng: so too Aṅgīrasa, O great sage,

sn8.11:3.4.eng: your glory outshines the entire world.”
